Perhaps you could shed some light on this for me: why does SpaceX insist on landing the center cores on a ship? Could they not just have it complete an orbit and land at one of the pads on the Cape? I know it won't be at perfect orbital height, but couldn't they push it to a greater altitude and use the decaying orbit for re-entry? Wow nothing like an idiot standing right in front of your field of view. Most recently became a new viewer to your channel and I must say that you have re-sparked my interest in the science and space happenings Tim, so Thanks for all of the wonderful, educational and professionally done videos on your channel and you should be commended as I know a ton of work goes into making these. So thanks again to you and your team of researchers and helpers for all of the great work that you do.

The only thing I’d like to comment on is your web store. I can surely see that it’s nice to give those in the aerospace industry a thank you/discount for the inspiration, what about the rest of us who don’t make six figure aerospace figures? How about a bone for all the active and retired veterans and service men and women who make or made the supreme sacrifice to give us the freedoms we have? Or the Volunteer Firefighters like myself and EMT/Emergency Service Personnel who race to the cause any time of day or night. Don’t get me wrong, I’m not bitching or bashing, just my Three Cents. I’m out of work at the moment & as much as I’d love to sport some of your great apparel, seeing that it looks like you put a lot of thought and design into them, it’s just not an option at this point in time. Being a graphic artist on the side I’ve done my share of T-shirt’s so I know what’s involved from the designs to the pricing.

Thanks for your ear and look forward to watching all of your future videos as well as telling anyone with similar interests about your channel.

God Bless & hope that you’re having a great week.
The third will be the lucky one.

Tim,
I've admired your work, and am especially interested in your attempts at high quality live streaming of launches from the Cape.
I witnessed the first Falcon Heavy launch last year, and came across video from YouTuber Astronomy Live.

He has perfected a custom tracking camera system, and his videos of the FH #1 and #2 launches are the best amateur footage I've seen.
My suggestion is for you to reach out to Astronomy Live and offer your live streaming channel to link up with his tracking camera system.

I think that your editorial content combined with his tracking video could put both of your channels into space!

Good luck with your efforts, even with the data dropouts, your coverage of the last launch was awesome!

Thanks,
John Pickens
Tabernacle, NJ

YouTube link:
https://youtu.be/cEZZkEXAD6Q

Loved your Falcon Heavy coverage and comments. I am a patron and long time space fan. The Air Force brought me to Patrick AFB Dec 15, 1968,  just a few days before the Apollo 8 launch. I supported the ARIA (Apollo Ranging & Instrumentation Aircraft) during the trans-lunar injection.  We, Space Coast EV Drivers, had  EV display near the rocket garden from 9 am to 5 PM. I showed my Red Model 3 RWD. We also had  a Bolt, Volt, Leaf & Prius Prime. I left a 5 PM and watch from home a few miles south. Loved Joe & Tim's coverage. I hope you all enjoyed your Florida trips. Looking forward to Ben's families favorite parts.

In SpaceX's live stream, it shows the LOX tank (i presume) at 45:09 and I got to thinking how do they orient the fuel towards the aft end with the pumps/turbos/combustion bits when in a near zero g environment when they aren't accelerating but just coasting, does the pressurized helium still provide the pressure to force fuel into/towards the engine? Or does that all just jossle around in the tank? Also, not sure if this is heat mirage (heat haze) or if this actually occurs, but at 49:06 at the final second stage shut down the mvac nozzle appears to wobble or distort. I don't know if it could be heat haze because they are in the vacuum of space and I believe heat haze requires air... So I'm guessing the mvac bell is just that flexible especially at those temperatures?
I love your channel but you had a bit of bad luck with the filming. Do not stop with this because you are doing a great job.

Tim, we love you and you have sparked my renewed interest in space. This video, alas, was below your usual excellence. All those cutouts.... and your previous videos have much better views. All your fellow Journalists were equally stoked and it was fun to see. I must admit that I prefer your previous videos where you are safe at "Everyday Astronaut Control" with good video feed, commenting on the SpaceX feeds and taking chats with no chance of Sunburn. Glad that all three boosters came down safe, and yeah, those sonic booms were worth the long wait. I assume the payload made it to the right orbit.....?

I really enjoy your channel, and your genuine enthusiasm and extensive knowledge (and will absolutely remain a subscriber!) but this stream was a debacle. 96.5 minutes of broadcast only to miss BOTH the launch AND the landings because of extraordinarily coincidentally-timed "technical issues" and outright plain old bad planning (camera placement DIRECTLY behind a guy such that his positioning perfectly obscured the landings, seriously?!).

Would've rather seen a talk-over commentary of the SpaceX feed; if you can't do better than this, do yourself a favour and save the time and expense of travelling to the launches live...

90% AND the fairings, it is still blowing my mind.  They put a satellite into high GTO and all but got their rocket back to use again.  How hard are they going to be pushing FH sales over expendable F9, don't you think?  Wow.
Question: why use Heavy for this satellite? It's ~6000 kg to GTO; Falcon 9 is supposed to be able to get over 8,000 kg to GTO.

Leave Tim alone, O ye complainers! Having been around when Super 8 mm sound motion picture film was the pinnacle of the average citizen's cinema equipment (only well-to-do folks could afford the much more expensive--and bulky and cumbersome--16 mm sound film cameras, film reels, projectors, and the film-developing fees), it's a little-appreciated ^miracle^ that such small, high-quality, all-electronic cameras and SmartPhones (to view the video, or even shoot video using their built-in "gum cams") are now not only available, but are affordable and ubiquitous. Also:


He is responsible for learning how to use the equipment (which I'm sure he took the time to do beforehand, unless he only very recently purchased the units), but he had ^no^ control over the availability and quality (data rate) of the internet circuit(s) that he could get there--plus, HE had to pay for the fuel, food, and any motel and/or parking fees that going there and setting up there involved (as well as deal with the heat, traffic, annoying insects [being a native Floridian myself, I know that the Cape is prime Chigger--"No-See-'Um" bugs--territory!], and other inconveniences along the way there); show the man some respect, because he earned it! His next such outing, I'm sure, will be much more polished and seamless.
1:28:18 lol perfect timing.

You missed the blast off AND the landings. Bummer

Nice video. Thanks.  A couple of suggestions. 1) Set lens to manual focus at infinity, and will avoid the autofocus grabbing something near (like crowd or bushes/treeline) to focus on.
